H0.text: Competition is the technique in which a scientist crosses two different varieties of corn to produce a single variety that has traits from both parents.

H1.text: Natural selection is the technique used by a scientist who crosses two different varieties of corn to produce a single variety that has traits from both parents.

H2.text: Selective breeding is the technique used when a scientist crosses two different varieties of corn to produce a single variety that has traits from both parents.

H3.text: Ecological succession is the technique where a scientist crosses two different varieties of corn to produce a single variety that has traits from both parents.

A4.text: Darwin distinguished natural selection from artificial selection as a separate process that is non-directed.

A5.text: Selective breeding (also called artificial selection) is the process by which humans use animal breeding and plant breeding to selectively develop particular phenotypic traits (characteristics) by choosing which typically animal or plant males and females will sexually reproduce and have offspring together.
